articles.name: Import Users from Active Directory Using Dsquery
articles.title: Import Users from Active Directory Using Dsquery
articles.body:
The easiest and most efficient way to integrate users from your organization’s Active Directory to your KnowBe4 console is to use our Active Directory Integration (ADI) feature. For more information on this feature, see our Active Directory Integration (ADI) Configuration Guide.

If you prefer to manually integrate your Active Directory information, you can use Dsquery to export your user data as a TXT file. Follow the steps listed below to generate your user list.

  1. Click Start, then right-click on Command Prompt. From the menu that displays, select Run as administrator.
    • For more information, see this Dsquery article from Microsoft Docs.
  2. Next, run the following command to generate a list of all actual users, excluding disabled accounts. This list will include each user’s first name, last name, and email address.dsquery * -filter "(&(objectClass=user)(mail=*))" -attr mail cn -limit 0 > users.txt

Once the user list is created, review the data for accuracy. Then, import your users by following the instructions in our Users and Groups article.

articles.name: Confirmation Email Issues
articles.title: Confirmation Email Issues
articles.body:
User accounts (for end users and admins) must be activated by clicking on the confirmation link in the confirmation email. Check your Spam or Junk folder to look for this confirmation email.

The confirmation email comes from do-not-reply@knowbe4.com. To ensure you will receive the confirmation email, add do-not-reply@knowbe4.com to your address book. 

It is also necessary to make sure our hostnames and IPs are whitelisted in your environment to allow emails from KnowBe4. 

For whitelisting, please see our Whitelisting Data and Anti-Spam Filtering Information article.

If the confirmation email was not received, request a new confirmation email using the URL for your instance:

  • United States: https://training.knowbe4.com/ui/users/signup/resend_confirmation_email
  • European Union: https://eu.knowbe4.com/ui/users/signup/resend_confirmation_email
  • Canada: https://ca.knowbe4.com/ui/users/signup/resend_confirmation_email
  • Germany: https://de.knowbe4.com/ui/users/signup/resend_confirmation_email
  • United Kingdom: https://uk.knowbe4.com/ui/users/signup/resend_confirmation_email

If you continue to experience issues, please reach out to our Support team by clicking here.

articles.name: Integrating COZYROC SSIS+ with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.title: Integrating COZYROC SSIS+ with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.body:
In this article, you’ll learn how to integrate COZYROC SSIS+ with your KSAT console. This integration pulls campaign and user data available via our reporting API into the COZYROC platform to migrate data from one place to another.

Note:Before you set up this integration, you'll need to copy the Reporting API Token, User Event API Token, and Product API Token from your KSAT Account Settings page. For more information, see the API section of our KSAT Account Settings: Account Integrations article.

To learn how to create a connection to KnowBe4’s REST API using COZYROC's REST Connection Manager, follow the steps below.

  1. On your Windows computer, navigate to Start > Visual Studio.
  2. Right-click Visual Studio, then select More > Run as administrator.
  3. Right-click on the Connection Managers tab and select New Connection.
  4. In the Add SSIS Connection Manager pop-up window, scroll down and select Connection manager for REST connections.
  5. Click Add….
  6. In the KnowBe4 Connection Manager pop-up window, select KnowBe4 from the Configuration drop-down menu.
  7. In the Server field, enter the server URL for your KnowBe4 instance using the following format: “https://[server].api.knowbe4.com”. For example, accounts on our EU server located at eu.knowbe4.com, must use the https://eu.api.knowbe4.com server URL.
    Note:For more information about KnowBe4’s API usage and URLs, see our Developer Documentation.
  8. Based on the APIs you would like to connect to, provide the values for the Events_Token, Reporting_Token, or PhishER_Token fields. For more information about these tokens, see the list below:
    • Events_Token: Use this parameter for creating custom events for users in KnowBe4. If you want to use this parameter, paste your User Event API Token in this field.
    • Reporting_Token: Use this parameter for pulling reporting data out of KnowBe4. If you want to use this parameter, paste your Reporting API Token in this field.
    • PhishER_Token: Use this parameter for pulling messages from KnowBe4’s PhishER SOAR. If you want to use this parameter, paste your Product API Token in this field.
  9. Click Test Connection to test your API connection.
  10. When you’re satisfied with your connection, click OK.

You’ve successfully established an API connection to your KnowBe4 instance.

To learn how to read your API data from your COZYROC and KnowBe4 connection, follow the steps below.

  1. On your Windows computer, navigate to Start > Visual Studio.
  2. Right-click Visual Studio, then select More > Run as administrator.
  3. Select Data Flow, then click the link to create a new Data Flow task.
  4. Select SSIS Toolbox, then drag the REST Source component onto the Data Flow page.
  5. Double-click on the REST Source component, then select KnowBe4 from the Connection drop-down menu.
  6. From the Resource drop-down menu, select one of the API parameters that you provided information for earlier.
  7. Click Columns, then select the KnowBe4 resource columns you want to read.
  8. Select Preview to ensure all necessary resource columns are included.
  9. Click OK. 
Note:For more information about this connection, see COZYROC’s KnowBe4 Connection article.

articles.name: Integrate Syslog with Your PhishER Platform
articles.title: Integrate Syslog with Your PhishER Platform
articles.body:
From the Syslog subtab of your PhishER Settings, you can configure the Syslog servers connected to your PhishER platform. System Logging Protocol, or Syslog, is a protocol that generates logs for network devices or servers. You can integrate Syslog servers with your PhishER platform to log when PhishER actions are triggered.

Connecting a New Syslog Server

To connect a Syslog server to your PhishER platform, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER platform.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Syslog.
  3. Click the New Syslog button in the top-right corner of the page.
  4. In the Add Syslog Settings pop-up window that opens, configure your Syslog server settings. To learn more about these settings, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. Name: In this field, enter a custom name for your Syslog server.
    2. Protocol: From the drop-down menu, select one of the following protocols: TCP, UDP, TLS, or TLS_INSECURE.
    3. Host: In this field, enter the host IP address of your Syslog server.
    4. Port: In this field, enter the port number of your Syslog server.
    5. Format: From the drop-down menu, select one of the following Syslog output formats: JSON, CEF, or LEEF. To learn more about these formats, see the Syslog Output Formats section of this article.
  5. Click Create.

Once your Syslog server is integrated with your PhishER platform, your organization can track and log events that occur in your platform. You can connect as many Syslog servers as you would like. If you create a PhishER action, you can select the Send to Syslog option under the Choose how you would like to report this action step.

Then, you can use the drop-down menu to select one of your Syslog servers. When your action is run, your Syslog server will log the event.

Managing Your Connections

From the Syslog subtab of your PhishER Settings, you can view all of your Syslog server connections. You can click a Syslog server’s name to open the Update Syslog Settings pop-up window. Then, you can update the information for that Syslog server.

For more information about the Syslog settings, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. New Syslog: Click this button to create a new Syslog server connection to your PhishER account.
  2. Name: This column displays the name of the Syslog server.
  3. Host: This column displays the host IP address of the Syslog server.
  4. Port: This column displays the port number of the Syslog server.
  5. Protocol: This column displays the protocol that the Syslog server uses to transport messages from the client to the server.
  6. Format: This column displays the output format for the Syslog server’s reports.
  7. Actions: This column displays the actions available to run on a Syslog entry. You can click the trash can icon to delete the entry.

Syslog Output Formats

You can select a JSON, CEF, or LEEF output format for your Syslog reports. For examples of each output format, see the subsections below.

JSONCEFLEF

JSON

For an example of a JSON output format, see below:

{ "receivedAt":"2019-05-20T17:39:43.351851Z", "reportedAt":"2019-05-20T17:39:39Z", "sender":"sender@example.com", "reporter":"reporter@example.com", "subject":"JSON Syslog Example", "priority":"medium", "category":"spam", "status":"received", "action":"Action 1", "tags":"TagSet" "permalink":"[[Unique URL]]" }

For more information about the attributes in this output format, see the table below:

Attribute Description
receivedAt

This attribute indicates the date and time of when the PhishER Inbox received the message.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSSSS'Z'
reportedAt

This attribute indicates the date and time of when a user reported the message.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SS'Z'
sender This attribute indicates the email address associated with the original source of the message.
reporter This attribute indicates the email address of the user who reported the message.
subject This attribute indicates the text found in the subject line of the original message.
priority This attribute indicates the message’s priority. PhishER uses the following priority levels: Low, Medium, High, Critical, and Unknown.
category This attribute indicates the message’s category. PhishER uses the following categories: Clean, Spam, Threat, and Unknown.
status This attribute indicates the message’s current state of PhishER analysis. PhishER uses the following statuses: Received, In Review, and Resolved.
action This attribute indicates the name of the PhishER action that triggered this report.
tags This attribute indicates the label attached to the message based on the message's attributes.
permalink This attribute indicates the URL specific to the message in your PhishER Inbox.

CEF

For an example of a CEF output format, see below:

start=1543962447998 rt=1543962447998 duser=destUserName@example.com suser=sourceUserName@example.com cat=unknown act=Action1 cs2Label=Status cs2=received cs3Label=Subject cs3=CEF Syslog Example cs4Label=Tags cs4=TagSet cs6Label=Permalink cs6=[[Unique URL]]

For more information about the attributes in this output format, see the table below:

Attribute Description
start

This attribute indicates the date and time of when the PhishER Inbox received the message. The date and time are represented in milliseconds.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSSSS'Z'
rt

This attribute indicates the date and time of when a user reported the message.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SS'Z'
duser This attribute indicates the email address of the user who reported the message.
suser This attribute indicates the email address associated with the original source of the message.
cat This attribute indicates the message’s category. PhishER uses the following categories: Clean, Spam, Threat, or Unknown.
act This attribute indicates the name of the PhishER action that triggered this report.
cs2Label=Status This attribute indicates the message’s current state of PhishER analysis. PhishER uses the following statuses: Received, In Review, or Resolved.
cs3Label=Subject This attribute indicates the text found in the subject line of the original message.
cs4Label=Tags This attribute indicates the label attached to the message based on the message's attributes.
cs6Label=Permalink This attribute indicates the URL specific to the message in your PhishER Inbox.

LEF

For an example of a LEEF output format, see below:

start=1541008403775 rt=1541009403775 duser=destUserName@example.com usrName=userName@example.com cat=Threat act=Test Action cs2Label=Status cs2=Pending cs3Label=Priority cs3=High cs4Label=Subject cs4=Testing Emailcs5Label=Tags cs5=Tag1,Tag2 cs6Label=Permalink cs6=[[Unique URL]]

For more information about the attributes in this output format, see the table below:

Attribute Description
start

This attribute indicates the date and time of when the PhishER Inbox received the message. The date and time are represented in milliseconds.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSSSS'Z'
rt

This attribute indicates the date and time of when a user reported the message.

Date and Time Format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SS'Z'
duser This attribute indicates the email address of the user who reported the message.
usrName This attribute indicates the email address associated with the original source of the message.
cat This attribute indicates the message’s category. PhishER uses the following categories: Clean, Spam, Threat, or Unknown.
act This attribute indicates the name of the PhishER action that triggered this report.
cs2Label=Status This attribute indicates the message’s current state of PhishER analysis. PhishER uses the following statuses: Pending, Received, In Review, or Resolved.
cs3Label=Priority This attribute indicates the message’s priority. PhishER uses the following priorities: Low, Medium, High, Critical, or Unknown.
cs4Label=Subject This attribute indicates the text found in the subject line of the original message.
cs5Label=Tags This attribute indicates the label attached to the message based on the message's attributes.
cs6Label=Permalink This attribute indicates the URL specific to the message in your PhishER Inbox.

articles.name: Code42 Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: Code42 Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Code42’s Incydr product with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by Code42 will be available for use in the SecurityCoach tab of your KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Creating Your Code42 API Client

Before you can set up this integration in your KSAT console, you will need to create an API client in your Code42 console. Code42 API client credentials are needed to complete the Setting Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section of this article.

To create the API client, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Code42 console.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Integrations > API Clients.
  3. Click Create new API client. When you click this button, the Create new API client pop-up window will open.
  4. In the Client name field, enter a name for your new API client.
  5. Under API Permissions, enable the Read option for Alert Rules and Alerts and Sessions.

  6. Click Save to create your new API client.
  7. Copy and save the Client ID, Secret, and Base URL values somewhere that you can easily access. You will need these credentials again to complete the Setting Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section below.

Setting Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you have created your API Client in your Code42 console, you can set up the integration in SecurityCoach by following the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate the Code42 vendor tile and click Configure.

  3. Enter the Client ID, Client Secret, and Base URL that you saved in the Creating Your Code42 API Client section of this article.

  4. Click Authorize.

Mapping Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Code42, you can map your users either through Mapping Rules (Recommended) or through a CSV File Upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Code42 on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our System Detection Rules by Vendor article.

Using the Integration

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Code42 on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our System Detection Rules by Can I Use with My Vendors? Aarticle.

Deleting the Integration in SecurityCoach

If you want to delete the Code42 integration from SecurityCoach, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  3. Locate the Code42 vendor tile and click Edit.
  4. Click Delete Integration near the bottom of the page.
  5. A confirmation pop-up window will open. If you are sure you want to delete the integration, click Confirm.

articles.name: Public ModStore Guide
articles.title: Public ModStore Guide
articles.body:
The Public Module Store, or Public ModStore, is a storefront that lets you view the training content we currently offer. You can browse through the content or search for content by title, language, subscription level, or content topics. To view the Public ModStore, click this link or navigate to training.knowbe4.com/ui/modstore/public in your web browser.

Note: While you can use the Public ModStore to see what content we offer, you must be logged in to a KnowBe4 account to preview content or add content to your library. To create an account, see the Registering for a New Account in the Public ModStore section of this article. If you have an account, see our ModStore and Library Guide article for more information about the features not available in the Public ModStore.

KnowBe4 partners with many e-learning and security awareness training providers to offer a variety of training content. We constantly add content to the Public ModStore to help keep your users informed about important security topics. Our training content can help users learn how to detect and prevent phishing and social engineering attacks, how to understand and abide by compliance requirements, and how to follow job-specific security requirements.

For more information about the types of content that we offer in the Public ModStore, see the list below:

  • Posters and Artwork: Posters and artwork are high-quality images and PDF files that you can share digitally with your users.

  • Newsletters and Documents: Newsletters and security documents are PDF files that you can print or share digitally with your users. These documents cover a wide range of cybersecurity topics to help reinforce the skills your users learn from their training.

  • Assessments: Assessments provide you with an overview of your organization's strengths and weaknesses. You can use assessment results to create a targeted security awareness training plan to meet your organization’s needs. We offer two types of assessments that you can assign to your users: the Security Culture Survey (SCS) and the Security Awareness Proficiency Assessment (SAPA).

  • Games: Games can reinforce the skills and information that your users are learning in an interesting and engaging way. Our games are SCORM-compliant and can be downloaded to use in your own Learning Management System (LMS).

  • Video Modules: Videos are MP4 files that users can watch in their browser or download to their device. Our videos cover a wide range of cybersecurity topics.

  • Training Modules: Training modules are interactive modules that cover a variety of cybersecurity topics. Our modules are SCORM-compliant and can be downloaded to use in your own LMS. Most training modules are brandable.

  • Mobile-First Modules: Mobile-first modules are training modules that are optimized to be viewed and interacted with on a mobile device. These modules are no longer than five minutes long and are designed to engage your users on their mobile devices. Our mobile-first modules are brandable and SCORM-compliant, so you can download these modules to use in your own LMS.

  • Audiocasts: Audiocasts are bite-sized audio lessons that deliver focused insights in a convenient, easily digestible format, perfect for on-the-go learning.

Each piece of content is displayed as a card. The card includes images of the content and brief details about the content. To learn more about a piece of content, you can click the card or click the View Details button.

When you click the card or the View Details button, you'll be taken to the content's Item Details page. On this page, you can read the content’s full description and view images from the content.

Browsing Suggested Content in the Public ModStore

In the Public ModStore, you can view rows of suggested content. To navigate these rows, click the left and right arrow buttons.

If you have not selected content filters, you will also see several suggestion categories. These categories contain suggestions based on content type. For more information about each suggestion category, see the list below:

  • Recommended: The Recommended section displays content that can be used for security awareness training. For KnowBe4 customers logged in to their account, this section will display uniquely curated content for their organization.
  • Foundational: The Foundational section displays content that will help your users get started with their security awareness training.
  • Monthly and Quarterly: The Monthly and Quarterly sections display content that we recommend you assign to your users on a monthly or quarterly basis. Assigning content to your users on a monthly or quarterly basis will help your users maintain their security awareness knowledge.

Searching for Content in the Public ModStore

You can also search for content by content type, topic, or keyword. For more ways to filter content, you can click Additional Filters.

Once you select a filter, all content that matches that criteria will display below a new header. This header shows the number of results that match your search, a Clear Filters button, and a Sort By drop-down menu.

For more information about both of these items, see the list below:

  • Clear Filters: Click this link to remove all of the content filters and return to the default view.
  • Sort By: Click this drop-down menu to sort your results by Most Popular, Most Recent, or Duration.

Previewing Content in the Public ModStore

While you can use the Public ModStore to see what content we offer, you must be logged in to a KnowBe4 account to preview this content. If you do not have a KnowBe4 account, you can click the Register button in the top-right corner of the page or the Register to preview button to create a free account. For more information about creating your account, see the Registering for a New Account in the Public ModStore subsection below.

You can sign up for a free KnowBe4 account to preview the training content that we offer. To sign up for an account, click the Register button in the top-right corner of the page or the Register to Preview button on any content’s Item Details page. When you click the Register or Register to Preview button, you will be taken to our ModStore Preview Portal page. On this page, you can fill out a form and then select Get Started to create your free account.

articles.name: Customize and View Phishing Activity Reports
articles.title: Customize and View Phishing Activity Reports
articles.body:
From the Reports tab of your KnowBe4 account, you can view Phishing Activity Reports to monitor your organization's phishing-related data. Phishing activity reports display comprehensive information about your users' Phishing Security Test (PST) results. You can also customize the reports to display specific data, such as PST data for individual user groups.

If you would like to export your Phishing Activity Reports for future use, you can export information from the report as a CSV file or export a report overview graph as a PDF file.

Note:Data from your KSAT console can take up to 24 hours to process and display in your phishing activity reports.

Customizing Phishing Activity Reports

When you create a phishing activity report, you can apply filters to the report to view specific data. For example, to view data for users who are in a specific group and phishing campaign, you would select the group in the User Groups filter and the phishing campaign in the Phishing Campaigns filter.

To learn about the filters you can apply to phishing activity reports, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Phishing Activity Reports: Use this drop-down menu to select your report type. You can select either All Phishing Activity or All Phishing Activity Grouped by User, depending on how you would like to organize your data. If you select All Phishing Activity, the report will display individual PSTs. If you select All Phishing Activity Grouped by User, the report will display PST data grouped by user. To learn more about these report types, see the All Phishing Activity and All Phishing Activity Grouped by User subsections below.
  2. Phishing Campaign Criteria: If you have PhishER, you will have the option to only display data for PhishFlip campaigns.
    Note:If you selected All Phishing Data Grouped by User in the Phishing Activity Reports drop-down menu, the Phishing Campaign Criteria filter will not display on the page.
  3. Phishing Campaigns: Use this filter to select the phishing campaigns that you would like to display data for.
  4. User Groups: Use this filter to select the user groups that you would like to display data for.
  5. Phishing Security Test Outcome: Use this filter to select the test outcomes that you would like to display data for.
    Note:If you selected All Phishing Data Grouped by User in the Phishing Activity Reports drop-down menu, the Phishing Security Test Outcome filter will not display on the page.
  6. Timeframe: Use this filter to select the date range that you would like to display data for. This date range is based on when the PST is scheduled to be sent.
  7. Add Filter: You can customize your phishing activity report with the following additional filters.
    • Template Attack Vectors: Use this filter to select the types of attack vectors that you would like to include in your report. The attack vectors are the types of attachments that were included in the PST. For more information, see our Phishing Campaign Attachments Overview article.
    • User Status: Use this filter to select Active or Archived if you would like to display only one status.
    • Exclude User Groups: Use this filter to select the user groups that you would like to exclude from the report. If a user is included in both the User Groups filter and the Exclude User Groups filter, the user will be excluded from the report.
    • User Groups Criteria: Use this filter to select specific criteria for the user groups that you would like to display data for.
    • Search User: Use this filter to search for specific users by name or by email.
      Note:If you selected All Phishing Data Grouped by User in the Phishing Activity Reports drop-down menu, the Search User filter will not be available.
    • Organization Chart: Use this drop-down menu to search by user name or job title. This filter shows user data for all organization levels under the selected users or job titles. For example, you can search for a specific job title, such as Director or VP. You can also select from the two additional settings below:
      • Select Include All Team Members to include the direct and indirect reports of the selected managers in the report.
      • Select Include Selected Manager to include the selected manager in the report. This check box will aggregate the data of the selected manager and any selected team member in the report.

After you select your filters, click the Apply Changes button.

Tip:After you click the Apply Changes button, you can click the Save Report button if you would like to view the report later. When you click the Save Report button, your report will automatically display in the Reports tab under the Saved Reports subtab. For more information about saving reports, see our Save and Send Reports article.

Viewing Phishing Activity Reports

After you customize your Phishing Activity report, your report will display a graph and a table. If you would like, you can export the graph as a PDF file and the table data as a CSV file.

To learn how to view your phishing activity reports based on report type, see the subsections below.

All Phishing Activity

If you selected All Phishing Activity for your report type, your report will display detailed information for each PST, while the All Phishing Activity Grouped by User report displays combined data for all PSTs that a user has received.

For this report type, you can view the bar graph to monitor the number of PSTs that have been delivered, failed, and reported. To view the exact numbers for each of these PSTs, you can hover your mouse over the bar graph. You can also remove a bar from the graph by clicking the corresponding label in the legend at the bottom of the graph. For example, you can click Failed from the legend to remove the Failed bar from the graph.

Below the graph, you can view a table that displays information about the phishing campaigns that each user is enrolled in. The table contains a separate row for each PST included in the campaign. For example, if a user is enrolled in one phishing campaign that includes three PSTs, the report will include three rows for the user.

You can customize the table by selecting columns to display and sort your results. To learn how to customize the table and download your report, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Manage Columns: Click this button to display a drop-down menu that contains a list of available columns. From the drop-down menu, you can deselect the default columns and select additional columns to display in the table.
    Note:If you export a CSV file of your report, the columns that you have selected in the Manage Columns drop-down menu will display in the CSV file. If you save your report by clicking the Save Report button near the top-right corner of the page, the columns that you have selected will display in the saved report.
  2. Arrow icon: Click this icon in the column headers to sort the results in the table.

All Phishing Activity Grouped by User

If you selected All Phishing Activity Grouped by User for your report type, your report will display more general data about your users' PST results by template topics, while the All Phishing Activity report displays data for individual PSTs.

For this report type, you can view the bar graph to monitor the number of PSTs that the users have failed and reported, including the number of clicks, replies, attachments opened, macros enabled, data entered, QR codes scanned, and users’ average Phish-prone Percentage. For callback campaigns available to Diamond subscriptions, the bar graph can also be used to monitor callbacks and callback data entered. To view the exact numbers for each of these events, you can hover your mouse over each bar in the bar graph. Next to the bar graph, you can also view the average Phish-prone Percentage, Phish-failure Percentage, and PAB-reported percentage.

Below the graph, you can view a table that displays information about the phishing campaigns that each user is enrolled in. The table contains one row for each user by combining the data for all of the phishing campaigns the user is enrolled in. For example, if a user is enrolled in one phishing campaign that includes three PSTs, the report will combine the data for the three PSTs into one row for the user.

You can customize the table by selecting columns to display and sort your results. To learn how to customize the table and download your report, see the screenshot and list below:

Note:In this table, the Calculated Phish-prone Percentage column displays each user's Phish-prone Percentage based on the selected filters. For example, if you have selected a specific phishing campaign in the Phishing Campaigns filter, this column will display each user's Phish-prone Percentage for that campaign.

  1. Manage Columns: Click this button to display a drop-down menu that contains a list of available columns. From the drop-down menu, you can deselect the default columns and select additional columns to display in the table.
    Note:If you export a CSV file of your report, the columns that you have selected in the Manage Columns drop-down menu will display in the CSV file. If you save your report by clicking the Save Report button, the columns that you have selected will display in the saved report.
  2. Arrow icon: Click this icon in the column headers to sort the results in the table.

Exporting Phishing Activity Reports

If you would like to export your Phishing Activity Reports, you can use the Export As button near the top-right corner of the filter options to generate a CSV or PDF File.

This will open a drop-down menu where you can choose to Generate CSV or Generate PDF. Generate CSV will generate a CSV file version of the report table. Generate PDF will generate the report’s graphs and Report Details found at the bottom of the report table.

In the top-right corner of your console, a notification bell will display when the report that you generated is ready to be downloaded. Your generated reports can also be downloaded at any time from the Download Center subtab. For more information, see the Download Center Overview.

articles.name: How to Update Control Tasks
articles.title: How to Update Control Tasks
articles.body:
In your KCM GRC platform, you can create tasks for your controls. Depending on your user role, you can update a task's details after you create it, including the approving managers, assigned user, description, due date, and evidence requirements. For general information about using tasks in your platform, see our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.

See the sections below to learn how to edit tasks for controls, including one-time tasks and recurring tasks. 

Updating One-Time Tasks

You can use one-time tasks for controls when the task doesn't need to occur on a recurring basis.

After you create a one-time task, you can update it by following the steps below:

  1. Navigate to the Controls tab of your navigation panel. 
  2. Select a control from the Name column.
  3. Click the Tasks tab.
  4. Select a task from the Name column. 
  5. On the View Task page, click the Update Task button. 
  6. Update the task details that you would like to change. 
  7. Click the Update button

Permissions for Editing One-Time Tasks

You can update the details for a one-time task, depending on your user role.

See the list below for information about which task fields you can update based on your user role. 

  • Account Administrator: Account Administrators can update all fields for all tasks that are in any status.
  • Group Lead: Group Leads can update tasks that they are the Group Lead for. They can edit the User Assigned field for tasks that are in any status.
  • Risk Administrator: Risk Administrators can update tasks for the controls that are mapped to risks or tasks that they are assigned to. They can edit all fields for tasks that are in the Active, Past Due, or Failed status.
  • Scope Administrator: Scope Administrators can update tasks that are in their allowed scopes. They can edit all fields except for the Approving Manager and Second-level Approving Manager fields for tasks that are in the Active, Past Due, or Failed status. 

Updating the Due Date for One-Time Tasks

If you update a one-time task's due date in the Due On field, the task's Start Date and End Date will change. You can select any date that is after the initial due date. You cannot select a new date that is before the initial due date, even if the new date is in the future. 

Important:Changing the task due date won't affect the task status. For example, if the task is in the Past Due status and you change the task due date to a future date, the task will still be in the Past Due status.

Updating Recurring Tasks

You can use recurring tasks for controls that require evidence on a recurring basis. After you create a recurring task, you can update the current task in the recurring task's schedule. 

Note:The current task that displays for the recurring task is either the most recent task or the earliest overdue task. When you update the current task, your updates will only affect that individual task. For example, if you update the current task's due date, the due date for the next scheduled task will default to its original due date.

You are unable to update all instances of a recurring task. However, you can cancel the recurring task and create a new recurring task. To learn how to cancel a recurring task, see the Canceling Recurring Tasks subsection below.

To update the current task of a recurring task's schedule, follow the steps below: 

  1. Navigate to the Controls tab of your navigation panel. 
  2. Select a control from the Name column.
  3. Select the Task Schedules tab. 
  4. Select a due date from the Current Due Date column. 
  5. On the View Task page, click the Update Task button. 
  6. Update the task details that you would like to change. 
  7. Click the Update button.

Permissions for Editing Recurring Tasks

Depending on your user role, you can update the details of a recurring task. 

See the list below for information about which of the task's details you can update based on your user role.

  • Account Administrator: Account Administrators can update all of the current task's fields for tasks that are in any status.
  • Group Lead: Group Leads can update tasks for the controls that their User Group is responsible for. They can edit the current task's User Assigned field for tasks that are in any status.
  • Risk Administrator: Risk Administrators can update tasks for the controls that are mapped to risks. They can edit all of the current task's fields for tasks that are in the Active, Past Due, or Failed status. 
  • Scope Administrator: Scope Administrators can update tasks that are in their allowed scopes. They can edit the current task's User Assigned field for tasks that are in the Active, Past Due, or Failed status.

Updating the Due Date for Recurring Tasks

When you edit the due date for the current task in a recurring task's schedule, you may notice that you have different options for selecting a date, depending on the task's frequency. After you edit a task's due date in the Due On field, the task's Start On and End On dates will also change. 

Important:Changing the task's due date won't affect the task status. For example, if the task is in the Past Due status and you change the due date to a future date, the task will still be in the Past Due status.

For information about changing the current task's due date for each task frequency, see the list below: 

  • Weekly: If the current task's due date has not passed, you can change the due date to up to one week after the initial due date. If the current task's due date has passed, you can change the due date up to two weeks after the initial due date. You cannot select a new date that is before the initial due date, even if the new date is in the future.
  • Monthly: If the current task's due date has not passed, you can change the due date to up to one month after the initial due date. If the current task's due date has passed, you can change the due date up to two months after the initial due date. You cannot select a new date that is before the initial due date, even if the new date is in the future.
  • Annually: If the current task's due date has not passed, you can change the due date up to one year after the initial due date. If the current task's due date has passed, you can not change the due date. You cannot select a new date that is before the initial due date, even if the new date is in the future.

Canceling Recurring Tasks

To cancel a recurring task, follow the steps below: 

Note:When you cancel a recurring task, the closed tasks and current tasks of the recurring task's schedule won't be deleted. 
  1. Navigate to the Controls tab of your navigation panel. 
  2. Select a control from the Name column.
  3. Select the Task Schedules tab. 
  4. In the Actions column, click the Cancel button. 
  5. In the pop-up window that opens, click the Yes button.

articles.name: Compliance Plus Guide
articles.title: Compliance Plus Guide
articles.body:
One of the most critical factors in meeting compliance requirements is your users’ understanding of those requirements. Just as security awareness training creates a strong human firewall, Compliance Plus content gives your users the tools they need to help mitigate risk.

This article has been written for users who may be unfamiliar with the KSAT console. If you are a compliance expert with little experience in the console, please reach out to your admin with any questions that you may have. For best results, we recommend running a compliance training campaign once every quarter.

Tip:If you are an admin granting your compliance experts access to the KSAT console, see our  Who Can Manage Compliance Plus Training? article.

Finding Compliance Plus Training Content

Before you can create a training campaign, you must first select the content to include in that campaign. First, find Compliance Plus content in the ModStore. Then, add the desired content to your account’s library. 

If you are browsing the ModStore, look for items with the orange compliance badge next to the title. If you would like to specifically search for Compliance Plus content, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console. 
  2. Navigate to the ModStore tab.
  3. On the Browse subtab, click on Additional Filters.
  4. From the Subscription Level drop-down menu, select Compliance Plus to browse all content specific to the Compliance Plus add-on.
  5. If you find the content you are interested in using, you can hover your cursor over the image and click View Details for more information. On the item details page, you can read the full content description and view the content.
  6. To add the content to your library, click the + Add to Library button. Once added, the content will be listed in the Library subtab, beneath the ModStore tab.
    • If an item shows the Already Added tag, the item is already available in your library and does not have to be added. 

Once you have added all of the Compliance Plus training you would like to your library, you can move on to Creating a Compliance Training Campaign.

Creating a Compliance Training Campaign

Once you have added content to your library, you can create a compliance training campaign. While logged in to your KSAT console, navigate to the Training tab. Then, click the +Create Training Campaign button in the top-right corner of the page.

On the campaign creation screen that opens, use the list below to create a compliance campaign with our recommended settings. 

  1. Campaign Name: Name your campaign something descriptive, such as "Compliance Training". 
    • This name will be seen by both admins and users completing the training. 
  2. Start Date: Select when you would like this campaign to run. 
  3. End Date: Select Relative Duration and use the default duration of three weeks. 
  4. Allow assignments to be completed after due date: Select this check box.
  5. Content: From the drop-down menu, select each of the training assignments you would like to include in this campaign.
    • In this menu, you can scroll vertically and horizontally as well as sort the list by each header. You can also type a keyword into the field to filter content.
    • Once you have selected the desired content, click out of the menu to view your content list. To reorder this list, you can click and drag the titles you would like to move. 
  6. Enable Content Survey: We recommend selecting this check box so that users will be prompted to take a survey after each assignment they complete. This setting is optional, but enabling surveys will help you keep in touch with users and see the effectiveness of your training strategy.
  7. Track Scores: Select this check box. This option saves the scores of each user for later review.
  8. Enroll Groups: Select Specific User. Then, from the drop-down menu, select the user group to enroll in this campaign. If this training is for everyone in your organization, select All Users.
    • If you do not know which group to include in this campaign, reach out to your admin for help.
  9. Enable automatic enrollment for new users: Select this check box. This option ensures that any users who are added to the selected groups at a later date will be enrolled in this training. 
  10. Enable progress reset for remedial training: This option is only recommended for remedial training campaigns. So, be sure that this check box is not selected.
  11. Notifications: We recommend creating notifications to welcome enrolled users and to remind them of the upcoming due date.

    To create a welcome notification, follow the steps below:

    1. Click the +Add Notification button. 
    2. From the Notification Type drop-down menu, select Welcome. 
    3. Select each check box next to User, Manager, and Admin. 
    4. In the drop-down menus next to each recipient type, keep the default templates selected.
    5. Click the Save button.

    To create a due date reminder, follow the steps below:

    1. Click the +Add Notification button. 
    2. From the Notification Type drop-down menu, select Remind Before Due Date. 
    3. Keep the default number of days before the due date.
    4. Check each check box next to User, Manager, and Admin. 
    5. In the drop-down menus next to each recipient type, keep the default templates selected.
    6. Click the Save button.
  12. Review your selected settings. When you are satisfied with the settings, click the Create Campaign button. 

After creating the campaign, users will be enrolled in this training on the start date. Once the campaign has started, you can move on to Monitoring a Compliance Training Campaign.

Monitoring a Compliance Training Campaign

To check on the progress of your users’ training, their scores, and other campaign metrics, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your KSAT console. 
  2. Navigate to the Training tab.
  3. On the Campaign subtab, find the compliance training campaign that you created. Click on the campaign name.
  4. The campaign’s Overview tab will display. On this tab, you will see a summary of the campaign, including a graph of users who have completed all of the content, the status, start date, relative duration, number of users, and more.
  5. To view user progress for the entire campaign, click on the Users subtab. 
    • This page is organized by subtabs, starting with All Users, then sorted by completion status.
    • The table is sorted alphabetically by user name. Under each user is a list of their enrolled content. To the right of the content name, you can see if the training was started, if and when it was completed, the user’s score for that module, and their current training status.
    • To find a specific user, enter their name or email address in the Search field. 

At any point during the campaign, you can download a spreadsheet of the user's progress. On the Users subtab of the campaign, click the Generate CSV button.

articles.name: Identifying Internal Emails Category Overview
articles.title: Identifying Internal Emails Category Overview
articles.body:
Using our Identifying Internal Emails landing pages in the KSAT console, you can provide your employees with examples of what your organization’s internal emails look like. This allows the employee to identify real organization emails and report potential phishing emails.

See below for more information on how to find and edit the landing pages for your organization’s needs.

Finding the Identifying Internal Emails Landing Pages

To find the Identifying Internal Emails landing pages, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. From your KnowBe4 console, go to the Phishing tab.
  3. Click the Landing Pages subtab.
  4. Click System Landing Pages.
  5. Click into the Identifying Internal Emails category.
  6. The search results will display all of our Identifying Internal Email landing pages.

Editing the Identifying Internal Emails Landing Pages

You can edit the majority of our built-in System landing pages, including the Identifying Internal Emails landing pages. To use our Identifying Internal Emails landing pages, you will first need to edit the landing pages in this category that you would like to use. When you save any edits to a built-in landing page, this customized copy will be saved to the Drafts category under the My Landing Pages area of the Landing Pages tab. Follow the steps below to edit an Identifying Internal Emails Landing Page.

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Navigate to your System Landing Pages by clicking Phishing > Landing Pages > System Landing Pages.
  3. Find the desired Identifying Internal Emails landing page.
  4. Click on the landing page's title to open the WYSIWYG editor.
  5. From the editor, select the Source button to edit the landing page’s source code.
  6. From the HTML editor, you can customize elements of the landing page, such as the image placeholders and background colors. At a minimum, you should change the placeholder image to show your users an example of this type of email.

See the example below for more information.

  1. Background Color: To edit the background color of the landing page, please follow the instructions in the code block shown below.

    :root { /*Colors*/ --clr-neutral-100: #ffffff; --clr-neutral-600: #000000; /* Change the background color of the landing page by replacing #8fc3ff with the hex code of your desired background color. */ --clr-theme: #8fc3ff; }
  2. Company Name Placeholder: This information will be automatically taken from your KnowBe4 console. For more information on placeholders, see our How To Use Placeholders article.

  3. Screenshot Placeholder: To edit the placeholder image on the landing page, please follow the instructions in the code block shown below.

    <!-- Replace the following image URL (https://helpimg.s3.amazonaws.com/landing_pages/identifying-internal-emails/add-image.png) with the image URL of your custom internal email screenshot. --> <img alt='Password reset email' class='screenshot-img' src='https://helpimg.s3.amazonaws.com/landing_pages/identifying-internal-emails/add-image.png' />
  4. Company Logo Placeholder: This image will be automatically taken from your KnowBe4 console. For more information on placeholders, see our How To Use Placeholders article.

Once completed, save your changes and preview your landing page. Be sure to add your custom landing page to a category in order to use it in phishing campaigns and notify your users. For more information on this process, see our How to Create and Edit Email Templates and Landing Pages article.

articles.name: Email Notifications and the Email Digest
articles.title: Email Notifications and the Email Digest
articles.body:
Whenever you have tasks to complete, tasks to approve, or other items to attend to in your KCM GRC platform, the system will automatically send you email notification reminders. In addition to individual notifications, if you are scheduled to receive more than one notification around the same time, the KCM GRC Email Digest combines your notifications into one email. This digest makes it so you'll receive a smaller number of notifications from your platform without missing important updates.

KCM GRC's email notifications will either have a subject line that is specific to the purpose of the email, or the subject line will state "KCM GRC Email Digest". All emails with the "KCM GRC Email Digest" subject line contain more than one notification.

All emails that are generated from KCM GRC are sent from the kcm[at]knowbe4.com email address. 

When Will I Receive an Email Digest Instead of Individual Emails?

Whenever you are set to receive two or more notifications within five minutes of each other, the notifications will be combined into one email digest.

This means, every time an email is triggered for you, KCM GRC queues the email for approximately five minutes and waits to see if you will receive an additional notification. Once this five-minute time span has passed and no additional emails have been triggered, your individual notification or email digest will be sent. 

The following list explains some of the most common scenarios where you would receive an email digest instead of individual email notifications: 

  1. You are assigned to a task as the User Responsible and you have multiple tasks that are due soon or are past due around the same time period.
    Important: An email digest can contain notifications for tasks that are due soon and tasks that are past due. 
    • Every day at 8 AM EST (12 PM UTC), the system checks for and sends task reminder notifications to the User Assigned. 
    • To learn more about KCM GRC's task reminder notifications, see the Control Task Notifications section below. 
  2. You are assigned to a task as the Approving Manager or Second-level Approving Manager, or if you are the group lead for a control, and you have multiple tasks that are awaiting your approval. 
    • Every day at 8 AM EST (12 PM UTC), the system checks for and sends reminder notifications to the Approving Manager, Second-level Approving Manager, or Group Lead if they have outstanding task approvals.
  3. Your administrator is creating new task schedules or one-time tasks for controls and they've assigned you as the User Responsible for these tasks.
    • You are notified whenever you are assigned to a new one-time task or task schedule for a control. If your administrator assigns you to a task, the system waits approximately five minutes before sending a notification. If your administrator assigns you to additional tasks in this five-minute time span, the notifications will be combined into one email digest.
    Note: For task schedules that use Effective Date Range, instead of notifying the User Assigned when the task schedule is created, the "New Task Assigned" email is sent on the Start Date of the first task in the schedule.

What Types of Notifications Are Not Included in the Email Digest?

The following types of emails are never included in an email digest:

  • Emails that are sent for the Executive Reports that you have set up. 
    • To learn more, see our Executive Reporting article. 
  • Emails that are sent to users that allow them to activate their new user account. 
    • To learn more, see our How to Activate Your Account, Access Your Account, and Reset Your Password article. 
  • Emails that are sent to users when they've forgotten their password. 
    • To learn more, see our How to Activate Your Account, Access Your Account, and Reset Your Password article. 
  • Emails to notify you that the CSV Export you've created is ready for download.
    • To learn more, see our Data Exports Guide. 

All other notifications are eligible for the KCM GRC Email Digest.

What Types of Notifications are Automatically Sent from KCM GRC?

All emails that are generated from KCM GRC are sent from the kcm[at]knowbe4.com email address. The system automatically sends email reminders as necessary, depending on the workflows that you're using in your platform. 

See the following sections to learn more about KCM GRC email notifications: 

  • Control Task Notifications
  • Vendor Questionnaire Notifications
  • Policy Campaign Notifications
  • Account Activation Notifications
  • CSV Export Notifications

Control Task Notifications

When you create a task schedule or a one-time task for a control, the user who is assigned to the task (User Assigned) will automatically receive notifications from KCM GRC.

If you assign an Approving Manager or a Second-Level Approving Manager to a task schedule or a one-time task, they will also receive reminder notifications as necessary.

If you've assigned a group to a control (under our user groups workflow), the Group Lead will receive reminder notifications for the control and its tasks, as necessary. 

Click each drop-down below to learn more about the notifications that users will receive for controls and tasks.

Note: All of the notifications explained in this section are eligible for the KCM GRC Email Digest. For more information, see the KCM GRC Email Digest section above.

  • When you create a control task schedule or a one-time task, the individual that you select as the User Assigned will automatically receive notifications on the following occasions: 

    1. To notify the user that the task or task schedule has been created and that they will be responsible for completing the task or tasks.
      Note: For task schedules using Effective Date Range, instead of notifying the User Assigned at the time that the task schedule was created, the "The Task Assigned" email is sent on the Start Date of the first task in the schedule. To learn more, see: Working With Task Schedules for Controls.
    2. To notify the user that the evidence they provided was insufficient and not approved.
    3. To notify the user that their task was approved.
    4. Several notifications are sent to remind the user to complete the task before it's due. Users also receive reminders when a task becomes past due. See the table below for details.

    Task reminder emails are determined by both the due date for the task and the frequency set for the task schedule. The table below defines when the User Assigned will receive a reminder email about their tasks.

    If...

    Then...

    Applicable to the following task schedule frequencies

    The task is due in 365 days or 1 year.

    The user will be sent a reminder that their task is due on this day of the following year.

    • One-Time
    • Every Five Years
    • Every Three Years
    • Every Two Years

    The task is due in 30 days.

    The user will be sent a reminder that their task is due in 30 days.

    • All frequencies listed above
    • Annually
    • Semi-Annually
    • Quarterly

    The task is due in 14 days.

    The user will be sent a reminder that their task is due in 14 days.

    • All frequencies listed above
    • Bimonthly

    The task is due in 7 days.

    The user will be sent a reminder that their task is due in 7 days.

    • All frequencies listed above
    • Monthly 

    The task is due the next day.

    The user will be sent a reminder that their task is due in one day.

    • All frequencies listed above
    • Weekly 

    The task is due today.

    The user will be sent a reminder email that their task is due today.
    • All frequencies listed above

    The task is past due.

    The user will be sent a reminder email that their task is past due. The user will continue to receive a daily reminder for 7 days by default. If you have changed the Task Fail Interval under your Account Settings area, the user will receive a daily reminder for the interval that is specified in this field.

  • When an Approving Manager is assigned to a task, they will receive an email notification daily under two occasions: 

    1. Once a task is complete and is awaiting their approval.
      Note: If there is a Second-level Approving Manager assigned to the task, they will receive a daily reminder once the task is awaiting their approval. To learn more, see: Task Approval Workflows. 
    2. Once the task has reached the Past Due status.

  • Under our user groups workflow, you can assign a group to a control and that group's Group Lead will be responsible for approving all evidence that is submitted for the control's tasks. See our Working with User Groups article to learn more about this workflow.

    When a group is assigned to a control, notifications are automatically sent to the Group Lead on the following occasions:

    1. When the group is assigned to the control.
      • This notification informs the Group Lead of three things: (1) That they are the group lead for a user group; (2) their user group has been assigned to a control; (3) as the group lead, they are responsible for approving the evidence that is submitted for the control.
    2. Once a control task is complete and the task evidence is awaiting approval from the Group Lead.
    3. When a task for the control is in Past Due status.

Vendor Questionnaire Notifications

Under the Vendor Risk Management module, you can send questionnaires to your vendors, or other third parties, to assess the level of risk involved in working with this entity. After the vendor has completed your questionnaire, you can create an "issue" in order to further discuss your concerns with an undesirable response to a question. To learn more about the Vendor Risk Management module, please see our Introduction Guide.

Many of the workflows under the Vendor Risk Management module are carried out through the vendor profiles that you've added to your account. For example, you will send and review questionnaires from this area. When creating a vendor profile, you assign a Vendor Contact and a Vendor Owner:

  • The Vendor Contact is the person who will be responding to your questionnaires on behalf of the third-party organization.
  • The Vendor Owner is the KCM GRC user from your organization who will manage the questionnaires for that vendor. 

Click each drop-down below to learn about the notifications that the Vendor Contact and Vendor Owner can receive from KCM GRC. 

Note: All of the notifications explained in this section are eligible for the KCM GRC Email Digest. For more information, see the KCM GRC Email Digest section above.

  • The table below lists the notifications that are sent to the Vendor Contact when carrying out workflows under the Vendor Risk Management module. 

    Notification Subject Line Triggering Action
    Please Confirm your New KCM Account (Preview) This notification is sent when you create a new user account for a Vendor Contact. 
    A New Questionnaire has been assigned (Preview) This notification is sent when you send a questionnaire to a vendor.
    KCM [Organization Name] created a new issue for [Questionnaire Name] (Preview) This notification is sent when you create one or more issues for a questionnaire.
    • The Vendor Contact will receive one notification for issues, per questionnaire, regardless of the number of issues created for the questionnaire.
    You have a response from [Organization Name] (Preview) This notification is sent when the Vendor Owner adds a response to the Vendor Conversation on the Issue Details page.
    Your questionnaire has been canceled (Preview) This notification is sent when you cancel a questionnaire that you have sent to the vendor.  

  • The table below lists the notifications that are sent to the Vendor Owner when carrying out workflows under the Vendor Risk Management module. 

    Notification Subject Line Triggering Action
    [Questionnaire Name] Questionnaire is Ready for Review (Preview) This notification is sent once the Vendor Contact has completed the questionnaire.
    You have a response from [Vendor Organization Name] (Preview) This notification is sent when the Vendor Contact adds a response to an issue from their vendor portal.
    • If the Vendor Contact adds a response to two or more issues within a five-minute time span, you will receive all notifications in one Email Digest. To learn more, see the KCM GRC Email Digest section, above.

Policy Campaign Notifications

Under the Policy Management module, you will create policy campaigns for the various policies and agreements that are required of the employees in your organization. Your users will receive and acknowledge the policy agreements by email. When your users acknowledge the policies, the acknowledgments are recorded in your KCM GRC platform. 

When creating a policy campaign, you will set up automatic email notifications for the users in your campaign so they can read and acknowledge policies. To learn about these email notifications, please see the User Experience section of our Policy Management Module Guide.

Note: If a user is enrolled in two or more policy campaigns at one time, they may receive multiple policy acknowledgment notifications in one email digest. To learn more about the email digest, see the KCM GRC Email Digest section above.

Account Activation Notifications

Whenever you add a new user to KCM GRC, they will immediately receive an email notification to activate their account. Additionally, if you enable a user that was previously disabled, they will receive an email to activate their account. To learn more about this email and account activations, please see our How to Activate Your Account, Access Your Account, and Reset Your Password article. 

CSV Export Notifications

Whenever you generate a CSV export from an area of your account, you will download the export from the Data Exports page. Depending on the amount of data included in your export, some CSV files may take more time to generate. Once your CSV file is ready for download, you will receive an email notification from KCM GRC. To learn more, please see our Data Exports Guide.

articles.name: Learner Support: Navigating the Learner Experience (LX)
articles.title: Learner Support: Navigating the Learner Experience (LX)
articles.body:
If you're reading this, it's likely that your organization is using the KnowBe4 Learner Experience (LX) to assign training content. You can customize your LX by selecting a preferred language, and you may also be able to earn badges and compete against your peers.

Note:If you are looking for information about the KnowBe4 Learner App, visit our Learner Support: KnowBe4 Learner App article.

Read below to learn more about these features.

Localization

You can set your preferred Learner Experience (LX) language by clicking your name in the top-right corner of your account and then clicking the desired language at the bottom of the drop-down menu. The interface for the LX will be translated to the selected language and courses that are available in that language that have not been started will default to that language.

For the full list of supported languages, visit our Multi-Language Support and Localization page.

Dashboard

The Dashboard tab displays an overview of your security awareness training, such as your training progress, phishing test results, badges, and more. If you have team members who report directly to you, you may also see a Team Dashboard. To learn more about the Team Dashboard, visit our Learner Support: Team Dashboard Overview for Managers article.

Note:The Dashboard tab is enabled and customized by your organization’s administrators. If enabled, your dashboard may not include all of the tiles and information that is listed in this article.

Click on the tabs below to learn more about each section of your dashboard.

The Training Progress tile shows your percentage of completed training assignments and includes a link to your training.

The assignments tile displays your five most recent training assignments, along with the training status and when the training is due. You can also click on a row to be taken to that specific training assignment.

The messages tile indicates how many unread messages you have.

You can click View Messages to go to the Messages tab.

The Phishing Test Results tile shows the number of reported phishing emails and phishing failures you have had.

The Reported Phishing Emails bar shows the number of simulated phishing emails you have reported, without also failing the test.

The Phishing Failures bar shows the number of negative interactions you have had with simulated phishing emails. Actions such as replying, downloading attachments, and clicking a link within the email are considered phishing failures.

The Personal Risk Score tile shows your calculated risk level. For more information about your Personal Risk Score and how to improve it, visit our Learner Support: SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score article.

The badges tile shows how many badges you have earned and includes a link to our Learner Support: How to Earn Badges article.

The leaderboard tile shows where your group ranks against other groups. It also includes a link to view the leaderboard.

Training

From the Training tab, you can see all of your assignments. If you are enrolled in multiple training assignments, your assignments will be displayed by priority. Any assignments that are past due will be shown first since they are the highest priority. Any incomplete assignments that will expire within the next 24 hours will also appear toward the top of your training screen.

To learn how to begin your training or how to resume a training course, please see step 4 of our Learner Support: A 4-Step Guide to Getting Started article.

Remember:For training progress to be accurately reflected in the system, it is crucial to close out the training window properly upon completion. This action ensures the completion status is updated in the console. Learners should be reminded that they must reach the last slide and select any Complete Training or similar buttons, and avoid selecting the browser's Close button before official completion.

Library

On the Library tab, you will find optional learning content that you can complete whenever you would like. Depending on the settings set by your organization’s administrators, you will either see a preselected library or a full library. Read the corresponding section below for more information about your Library tab.

Preselected Library

The content listed in a preselected library has been selected by your organization. We encourage you to browse these options and find content that interests you.

When you find a piece of content that you’d like to complete, follow the steps below:

  1. Click on the content’s image or the View Details button.
  2. On the page that opens, review the content description and the estimated time you will need to complete the content.
  3. If you would like to begin this optional learning content, click the Start button.

If you start a piece of content but do not complete it, you’ll see the In Progress tag on the content’s image. Once you complete a piece of content, you’ll see the Completed tag. You can hover your mouse over the completed content’s image to see your time spent, completion date, and a link to download your completion certificate.

Full Library

Content listed in a full library is organized into different types of recommendations and includes a search feature.

For more information about the different types of recommendations, see the list below:

  • Recommended For You: The content listed in this section has been selected by KnowBe4’s Artificial Intelligence Driven Agent (AIDA). AIDA recommends content based on the following information:
    • Optional content that you have completed.
    • Required content that you have completed on the Training tab.
    • How you have rated your completed required content.As you complete more content and provide more feedback, you will receive more relevant recommendations.
  • Recommended by Your Organization: You will only see this section if your admins have enabled it. The content listed in this section is optional learning that has been selected by your organization.
  • Recommended Topic: Social Media: The content listed in this section covers social media, which is one of our most popular and relevant topics.

At the top of the Library tab, you can browse your recommended content by using the Content Types and Topics drop-down menus or by searching for keywords. If you have set your training language, content available in that language will be shown first in your recommendations and search results.

When you find a piece of content that you like, follow the steps below:

  1. Click on the content’s image or the View Details button.
  2. On the page that opens, review the content description and the estimated time you will need to complete the content.
  3. If you would like to complete this piece of content, click the Enroll button.
  4. From the modal that opens, click the Start Now button to begin the content now. Or, click the Save for Later button to complete the content at a later time.
    • Content that you’re enrolled in but haven’t started can be found in the Continue Learning section of your library.

If you start a piece of content but do not complete it, you’ll see the In Progress tag on the content’s image. This content will be listed in the Continue Learning section of your library.

Once you complete a piece of content, you’ll see a Completed tag on the content’s image. You can hover your mouse over the completed content’s image to see your time spent, completion date, and a link to download your completion certificate.

Messages

The Messages tab lists messages sent to you from your organization. If you have unread messages, you will see a number next to this tab.

Once you have read a message, click Mark as Read to move the message to the Read Messages section at the bottom of the page. You can review any message in the Read Messages section by clicking on the message subject.

Leaderboard

The Leaderboard tab shows where you or your group rank in a friendly competition with your colleagues. For more information about leaderboards and how they work, see our Learner Support: Leaderboard Guide.

Badges

As you complete your training, you will have the opportunity to earn badges. You'll earn them automatically based on various achievements. You can click the Badges tab to see what badges you've received and what badges are still available to you.

To learn more information about how to earn badges, see our Learner Support: How to Earn Badges article.

User Profile

You can access your user profile by clicking on your name in the top-right corner of your account, and then clicking on Profile from the drop-down menu. In your profile, you can update information such as your name, phone number, and password.

Once you have made your updates, click the Save button to save the changes. You will be taken back to the LX home screen.

If you experience any problems with the LX please contact our support team.
